category.label: Misc

category.term: Journey to the Center of the Earth
category.label: Misc

content.div:
HONOLULU - The always affable Dwayne Johnson is lounging in a deluxe suite at the exclusive Kahala Hotel and Resort, far from the bustle of downtown Waikiki Beach. .

He's here to promote the special-effects, 3-D fantasy film, Journey 2: The Mysterious Island, which opens in theatres Feb. 10.

As usual, the six-foot-five Johnson is funny and forthcoming during our chat, and becomes serious only once: when it's mentioned he seems grounded for a Hollywood star.

"It's easy to be grounded when I remember that, three miles from here, there was an efficiency (studio) apartment where I lived with my mom and dad," says the 39-year-old, who was born in Hayward, California, but raised as a young teen in Hawaii. "We came home one day, and there was an eviction notice on the door, and I remember my mom crying."

He also recalls some tough times "as a troubled youth," but he managed to turn himself around at Honolulu's President William McKinley high school, "when a couple of (football) coaches believed in me, even when I didn't."

That led to graduation, a University of Miami football scholarship, a popular wrestling stint as The Rock, and a mostly successful movie career that has spanned more than a decade.

Now, he's starring in the Brad Peyton-directed Journey 2, which references Jules Verne's The Mysterious Island and Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea, as well as hinting at Robert Louis Stevenson's Robinson Crusoe and Jonathan Swift's Gulliver's Travels.

Johnson replaces Brendan Fraser in the sort-of sequel to 2008's Journey to the Center of the Earth 3-D. This time around, 17-year-old Sean Anderson (Josh Hutcherson) teams up with his mother's new husband, Hank Parsons (Johnson,) to find the teen's missing grandfather (Michael Caine), who has sent out a coded alarm after being stranded on a Pacific island.

After crashing in a helicopter on a rescue trip, Sean and Hank also end up stranded on a tropical island with their guide Kailani (Vanessa Hudgens), and her father, a goofy helicopter pilot, Gabato (Luis Guzman). On the island, the group discovers giant lizards, miniature elephants, gold mountains, deadly floods, and the missing grandfather, warning them they must find a way off the island or be killed.

Filmed on location in and around Oahu in Hawaii (and at production studios in Wilmington, North Carolina), the movie is a special-effects extravaganza with lots of action and some comic relief.

Still, it relies on Johnson's ability to combine humour with macho posturing, somewhat like his popular wrestler persona, The Rock. And it's no coincidence.

"Dwayne is up for any challenge, and whenever he gets into something, he wants to own it," says the Toronto-based Peyton, who also directed 2010's animated flick, Cats and Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore.

As a co-producer of the movie, Johnson did "own it" in more ways than one. When he signed on, he re-fashioned his character to suit his strengths. "The fun part," he says, "was creating this from scratch."

To that end, there are some funny bits, with Johnson "popping my pecs, because it's one of my gifts." In another scene, he shows off his singing voice and his ukulele playing. "In the Polynesian culture, we love to sing and dance," notes the actor, who's from Samoan ancestry.

"Tone is everything," Johnson says, "so we wanted to make sure the audience is having a good time, and we look like we're having a good time."

On set and off, he was also the unofficial goodwill ambassador. That's confirmed by Hudgens, the diminutive actress and singer who was one of the attractions in the High School Musical franchise.

"He's awesome," says Hudgens of Johnson. "And, I mean, he really is an extremely large guy. I thought that he was going to be big, but you can't imagine how massive a human being can be until you meet him."

In sharp contrast to his imposing presence, she says, "he's such an incredibly sweet guy, and he's very genuine, really funny, and always very charming."

And while Johnson dabbles in the occasional adult thriller, he's been focused on family films and action pictures over the last few years.

Besides Journey 2 this year, he co-starred in Fast Five last year, and will reprise his role as Special Agent Luke Hobbs in The Fast and Furious 6, which will begin filming in Germany by spring. He's preparing to shoot Pain and Gain in a few weeks with Transformers director Michael Bay. He also confirms that he's developing a biopic of African-American country singer, Charlie Pride.

In April, he's back as his wrestling persona, The Rock, the featured attraction in WrestleMania XXVIII. Last year, he was the host of WrestleMania XXVII.

Is he regressing?

Despite his busy film career, he says he can't resist the wrestler in him.

"I love it, and I love the fans," Johnson admits. "Do I need it? No, it's not about the money. But there's nothing like engaging 70,000 people. It's electric."

entry.title: From The Avengers to Lincoln, performances to watch in 2012

link.Abstract: A teen gladiator enters a reality-TV fight club. Johnny Depp gets in touch with his inner vampire. And superheroes battle aliens from outer space.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract: 2) The James Bond Franchise - While we're not sure which gets more butts in the seats: James Bond or his scantily clad love interests. The tired Bond franchise was revived when Daniel Craig took over in Casino Royale and Quantum of Solace, but now the entire series may be in jeopardy. Production on the 23rd film was recently suspended indefinitely due to studio MGM’s financial troubles. Hollywood bigwigs: please see this as a sign and let the franchise go out on a high note, OK?
link.title: James Bond

link.Abstract: When the critics can't agree on a juggernaut title to sweep awards sea-son, you know Hollywood missed a beat. By this time of year, there's usually one movie that starts snowballing, pulling hardware to its chest at exponential speed, and getting all the magazine-cover attention.
link.title: 10 memorable movies from 2011

link.Abstract: The movie year is almost over, and the numbers are pretty dismal: a 4.9 per cent drop in the North American box office, making it the worst year since 1995. This is an industry that is accustomed to automatic growth, just as it used to be with the stock market. Just imagine how you'd feel if you put all your RRSP money into Mars Needs Moms (budget: $150 million, sales: $39 million).
link.title: Bleak year for movie business

link.Abstract: Fast Five, Hangover II and Thor were among the most-pirated movies of 2011, according to a new list from the blog TorrentFreak. But some of the year's other biggest grossers at the global box office - including the latest Pirates movie - are notably absent from the top 10.
link.title: Fast Five tops list of pirated films
